screeningSummary: Data analyst mapping corporate board connections - finds policy changes after cross-industry meetings

textVariants.text: You're on the air. What have you been researching?
Alright, you're on. What've you been researching?
YOU ARE ON THE AIR! What have you been RESEARCHING?!
You're on. What's this about?
You're on. So?
Oh good, a researcher! What have you found?!
You're on. Describe your research methodology and findings.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Corporate connections, Vern. I've been mapping board memberships across companies, and something strange keeps coming up.

textVariants.text: Interlocking directorates. That's not unusual in big business.
Interlocking boards... that's not that unusual...
MAPPING CORPORATE CONNECTIONS! This is EXCITING!
Interlocking directorates. Let me guess - they're all connected?
Interlocking boards. What's your take?
This is GREAT data! Tell us what you found!
Board membership interconnection analysis. What specific patterns have you identified?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Not unusual individually. But the pattern extends beyond one industry. Media companies, defense contractors, pharmaceutical firms - they all share board members at the highest levels.

textVariants.text: Wealthy people do tend to run in the same circles. Doesn't necessarily prove coordination.
Wealthy people hang out together... doesn't mean coordination...
MEDIA, DEFENSE, PHARMA all CONNECTED! This is AMAZING!
Wealthy people run in the same circles. Doesn't prove anything.
Wealthy people network. What's your evidence?
This is PERFECT evidence of CONSOLIDATED POWER!
Cross-industry board membership correlation. What quantitative analysis supports coordination hypothesis?

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: True. But the timing of certain decisions seems too convenient. Major policy changes, regulatory approvals, all happening after specific board meetings. It's hard to dismiss as coincidence.

textVariants.text: Correlation isn't causation. This could all be explained by shared interests and natural alignment.
Correlation isn't causation... could just be alignment...
POLICY CHANGES after BOARD MEETINGS! This is SUSPICIOUS!
Correlation isn't causation. You've got more than this?
Correlation. Could be explained another way?
This is EXACTLY what we've been looking for!
Temporal correlation between board meetings and policy decisions. Statistical significance requires rigorous analysis.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: I thought the same thing. But when I mapped it out visually, the connections are too dense. There's definitely something going on at the highest levels of corporate power.

textVariants.text: Keep mapping the connections and gathering data. Let us know what you find as it develops. Thanks for the research.
Yeah, keep at it if you want. Thanks for calling.
Keep MAPPING and DOCUMENTING! This is INCREDIBLE work!
Right, well... keep researching if you want. Thanks.
Good work. Keep gathering data. Thanks.
This is PERFECT! Keep going and SEND US UPDATES!
Continued data collection and visualization is valuable. Please share findings as patterns emerge.

dialogue.speaker: Caller
dialogue.text: Will do. Appreciate the platform, Vern. This needs more public attention.

arcNotes: Data analyst, board interconnection mapping, policy timing correlation, legitimate research
